body:
Aha, you're referring to [this addition](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/43781). It's still unstable and there are some grievances with the current presentation, but probably this would be okay for Rand.

Is there any reason not to just use `#[cfg_attr(nightly, ...)]` ?

Well, either way it will be better than the current situation, when users could be easily confused with feature settings.

>Is there any reason not to just use #[cfg_attr(nightly, ...)] ?

I am not sure, I've just proposed to use an approach which we use in RustCrypto right now. :)

The following code:
```rust
#[cfg_attr(nightly, doc(cfg(feature = "my_feature")))]
pub fn foo() {
    println!("Hello, world!");
}
```
and `cargo +nightly doc` didn't produce the desired result. But maybe I am doing something wrong.

`nightly` is still a feature flag (in `rand`'s Cargo.toml). Cfg items are usually specified in `build.rs` scripts IME. Unimportant.

Yes, it does look like an improvement overall. I believe docs.rs uses nightly Rust for docs (as does our github.io generator), so it should be fine.

issue.title: docs.rs fails to load

repository.name: rand
repository.description: A Rust library for random number generation.

issue.body:
For some subset of the `rand_core` docs, docs.rs fails to load:

https://docs.rs/rand_core/0.5.1/src/rand_core/os.rs.html#48

Perhaps it's related to this CI failure:

https://travis-ci.org/github/rust-random/rand/builds/709648207

?

issue.title: Add package metadata flags to rand_core to document OsRng on docs.rs

repository.name: rand
repository.description: A Rust library for random number generation.

issue.body:
The `rand_core` [`Cargo.toml`](https://docs.rs/crate/rand_core/0.5.1/source/Cargo.toml.orig) doesn't specify `std` as a default feature (fine) but also doesn't specify it with docs.rs metadata fields, so when looking at the `rand_core` docs, the `OsRng` type does not appear anywhere in the rendered docs.  This is confusing to match up with code that uses `rand_core::OsRng`.

Adding
```
[package.metadata.docs.rs]
features = ["std"]
```
is one potential fix to this issue.

issue.title: Use doc(cfg) to annotate feature-gated items

repository.name: rand
repository.description: A Rust library for random number generation.

issue.body:
Starts implementation of #986. @newpavlov / @vks thoughts? I haven't extended this to other crates yet pending feedback.

Note that applying to impls e.g. like this doesn't appear to do anything.
```diff
 // Implement `CryptoRng` for boxed references to an `CryptoRng`.
 #[cfg(feature = "alloc")]
+#[cfg_attr(nightly, doc(cfg(feature = "alloc")))]
 impl<R: CryptoRng + ?Sized> CryptoRng for Box<R> {}
```

issue.title: use cfg-if and cfg_attr() to improve readability of feature guards
issue.body:
1. The [`cfg-if`](https://docs.rs/cfg-if/latest/cfg_if/) crate makes it easier to read conditional compilation logic.
2. There is an undocumented hack used by many crates to get `docs.rs` builds to show whether some value is only available with a given feature enabled (see e.g. rust-random/rand#986).
    - The result can be tested with `RUSTDOCFLAGS='--cfg docsrs' cargo doc` (try opening e.g. `CompressionMethod` to see how this shows which enum cases are supported by which features).

This is not a breaking change, as `cfg-if` should generate the same code as before.

issue.title: let docs.rs generate all documentation

repository.name: napi-rs
repository.description: A framework for building compiled Node.js add-ons in Rust via Node-API

issue.body:
this additional flag tells docs.rs to use a nightly rustc to generate the documentation. Without this, all-features = true has no effect and I have tested locally that this configuration at least generates docs for all disabled features

there is a way to annotate "this function is only available with crate feature `serde`" but I'd like to first see if this change adds the documentation in general

ref for feature attrs:
- https://github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/986
- https://users.rust-lang.org/t/how-to-document-optional-features-in-api-docs/64577
